title: Data Visualization
text:
I created this visualization during my Data Science course. The task was to explore the mtcars dataset.



Negative correlation: Higher horsepower generally means lower MPG (r ≈ -0.78)
Outliers: Some cars have unusual MPG for their horsepower
Statistical insight: Every 10 HP increase ≈ 1.5 MPG decrease


“This insight helped me understand engine efficiency trade-offs in automotive design.”





Dataset Documentation
ggplot2 Cheatsheet


This project taught me the importance of choosing the right visualization for continuous variables.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: Recently I have been using Deepseek and Gemini to assist me with some of my works. I decided to use Deepseek and Gemini because there are free to use. Gemini had an offer which allowed students to use their GenAI for free, for 1 year. GenAI has helped me alot with troubleshooting errors when it comes to my work, rather than relying on stackoverflow which was usually used during my polytechnic days.

title: Data Visualization
text:
During my second year Psychology Research Methods course, I conducted an independent study exploring how lifestyle factors affect academic outcomes. As a student juggling coursework, part-time work, and extracurricular activities, I noticed my own grades fluctuated with my sleep schedule. This sparked my curiosity: Was there a quantifiable relationship between sleep and academic performance across the student population?



Timeline: Conducted over Fall 2023 semester
Sample: 85 undergraduate students (voluntary participation)
Method: Daily sleep logs + end-of-semester GPA collection
Ethics: Anonymous data collection with institutional approval
Personal Motivation: To make data-driven decisions about my own study habits

title: Data Visualization
text: #| label: fig-sleep-patterns #| fig-cap: “Average Sleep Hours by Day of Week and Assignment Load” #| warning: false # Load required libraries library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)

title: Data Visualization
text:
During my Introduction to Statistics course in Year 2, we conducted a class survey about lifestyle habits. As a student who often pulled all-nighters during exam season, I was particularly curious about sleep patterns. I collected data from 50 classmates over a typical academic week (Monday to Friday) to explore the relationship between academic workload and sleep duration.



Participants: 50 undergraduate students (25 male, 25 female)
Data Collected: Daily sleep hours, day of week, assignment deadlines
Time Period: One typical academic week
Collection Method: Anonymous Google Form with self-reported data
